page.title: 01ROMSEY - INTRODUCTION
page.content: ROMSEY is situated where town meets country. On one side it is almost urban sprawl right down to Southampton. To the south-east many new estates are being built destroying copses and open areas. But for the green belt Romsey would be a suburb of Southampton and Portsmouth. On the north side of Romsey there are new companies housed in an industrial estate making things such as plastic, shoes and spices. In the Middle Ages the wool industry made Romsey rich. Salmon and trout thrive in the cleaner Test. Most farms are dairy so Romsey does not have the problem of fertiliser polution or destruction of hedges to make larger fields. There are many buildings with preservation orders and tourists flock in to see the Norman Abbey and Broadlands.
